text: this is Cape Flattery Washington the
northwest corner of the continental
United States this crossroads of to
waterways results in an abundance of
marine life it's also a region
undergoing big changes in water
chemistry affecting both the wildlife
and the people who call this place home
Cape Flattery is on the Makah Indian
Reservation about 1,700 tribal members
live here many make their living fishing
others harvest shellfish on the rocks
and beaches nearby in the past decade
scientists have found the water's here
are becoming more acidic scientists are
still trying to figure out why this is
happening but in the meantime the Macau
worried their source of both food and
traditional crafts could one day
disappear Myka McCarty is the tribes
former chairman he's working with marine
scientists to find out what's behind
these changes he jumps across the tide
pools to the intertidal zone where
barnacles and mussels cling tightly to
the rocks McCarty and scientists believe
acidic waters are weakening the animals
making it more difficult for them to
hang on he's got to keep his balance
there's no lifeguard here McCarty has
done this before he waits for a break
pulls out his pocketknife and scraped
the shellfish into a bag he pulls up a
gooseneck barnacle with its distinctive
orange fleshy stem it's considered a
delicacy by the macaw as well as other
coastal people throughout the world
McCarty has also found a few mussels and
a chiton tasty treats that will go into
a stew tonight back home as well as
eating shellfish the macaw people use
some species to make necklaces
instruments and other things for their
ceremonial regalia their lives are tied
to this coastline in its riches they
can't pick up and move somewhere else
still McCarty says they will adapt to
the future as best I can
you
